snippet: John O. Brennan described agency interrogators as “patriots” and pointedly refused to say that brutal methods like waterboarding amounted to torture.
abstract: Central Intelligence Agency Director John O Brennan challenges Senate Intelligence Committee findings that brutal tactics agency used in detention and interrogation program following Sept 11, 2001, attacks amounted to torture and were largely ineffective; acknowledging depth and complexity of committee's research, Brennan nonetheless labels report flawed and partisan.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and MATT APUZZO
byline.contributor: Mark Mazzetti reported from Langley, and Matt Apuzzo from Washington. Peter Baker contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: John O. Brennan described agency interrogators as “patriots” and pointedly refused to say that brutal methods like waterboarding amounted to torture.

headline.main: C.I.A. Director Defends Use of Interrogation Tactics, Avoiding Issue of Torture
headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Director Rebuts Report, Calling Interrogators ‘Patriots’
